content.text:
<task>
Create a file called hello.py containing print('hello world')
</task>

# task_progress RECOMMENDED

When starting a new task, it is recommended to include a todo list using the task_progress parameter.


1. Include a todo list using the task_progress parameter in your next tool call
2. Create a comprehensive checklist of all steps needed
3. Use markdown format: - [ ] for incomplete, - [x] for complete

**Benefits of creating a todo/task_progress list now:**
	- Clear roadmap for implementation
	- Progress tracking throughout the task
	- Nothing gets forgotten or missed
	- Users can see, monitor, and edit the plan

**Example structure:**```
- [ ] Analyze requirements
- [ ] Set up necessary files
- [ ] Implement main functionality
- [ ] Handle edge cases
- [ ] Test the implementation
- [ ] Verify results```

Keeping the task_progress list updated helps track progress and ensures nothing is missed.

content.thinking: The user wants to create a file hello.py containing print('hello world'). Need to include task_progress checklist in tool call. Use write_to_file tool. Provide checklist with steps: analyze requirements, create file, verify content. Mark first step completed? We are about to create file, so maybe mark analyze requirements done. We'll include checklist with first item done, second pending. Use write_to_file with path hello.py and content. Set task_progress accordingly.

content.text:
<write_to_file>
<path>hello.py</path>
<content>print('hello world')</content>
<task_progress>
- [x] Analyze requirements
- [ ] Create hello.py with required content
- [ ] Verify file creation
</task_progress>
</write_to_file>
